additionalFields.description:
I wonder if we’re overlooking an important implication of AI and generative AI for the future of the enterprise. If, as seems to be the case, many employees will use generative AI applications to assist them and interactively support their work, then a new style of work is emerging. Success for an employee will mean making the most of the AI tools with which they collaborate. We will want to hire employees who are especially good at working interactively with AI (remember how the ability to use word processors and spreadsheet applications were qualifications for a job in the old days?). We will design employee roles to maximize the benefit of collaboration with AI tools. Remote work and the gig economy have already dramatically changed the nature of work; generative AI is another potential disruption on the horizon.

Read the full blog
additionalFields.headline: AI and Collaboration: A Human Angle

additionalFields.description:
We’ve all been busily transforming for the last few years. Now there’s this big AI thing. How does it relate to the rest of our transformation? Should we be changing or rethinking our transformation plans?

The easy answer is no, but there are some subtleties. We transform to increase our agility in the face of change, and we accept that the future will see major changes and disruptions. The sudden attention demanded by AI is just a vindication of that belief. You can even test yourself: can your company respond quickly and effectively to the sudden, disruptive intrusion AI represents? If so, you may be further along in your transformation than you thought. As we’ve always said, responding appropriately requires setting up nimble governance processes, an ability to experiment, a culture of innovation, and automation of the good practices, security, and resilience you require.

Read the full blog
additionalFields.headline: Transformation and AI

The ability to effectively leverage these technologies to drive decision-making and gain insights is becoming critical for success. According to Accenture, “this means both building talent in technical competencies like AI engineering and enterprise architecture, and training people across the organization to work effectively with AI-infused processes." However, the supply of skilled workers in the cloud computing industry remains limited, creating a significant challenge for organizations looking to implement cloud projects. This shortage of skilled workers can lead to increased costs, delays in project implementation, and reduced competitiveness. To address this challenge, customers are investing in training and development programs for their existing employees.

Read the article

additionalFields.description:
It won’t surprise you to hear that there’s been lots of excitement and speculation about generative AI in our meetings with AWS customer executives lately. The question on their minds is: “What does this mean for my business?” That’s a good way to frame the question; it’s not about what generative AI can do, but what it can do for your business. And the seeds of the answer are there in that framing as well. How generative AI will affect your business depends on how you and your competitors will use it to innovate new business models and derive new competitive advantages. It’s not about what the technology itself does—exciting as that is—but about how you will combine it with other technologies, your people’s skills, your values and competencies, and your distinctive vision.

additionalFields.headline: What Will Generative AI Mean for Your Business?

additionalFields.subHeadline: How can organizations free their teams to move faster with governed data across the data lifecycle? Find out how Pinterest implemented a modern governance strategy that put customers first and empowered employees to drive innovation.
additionalFields.description: The growth of data over the past few years is astounding: an estimated 97 zettabytes (1021 bytes) will have been created or replicated in 2022 alone. To put that number into perspective, to store 97 zettabytes on 1 terabyte hard disks, you’d have to stack the disks 27 million times—equal to roughly 15 round trips between the earth and the moon. These zettabytes of data have created great opportunities to create personalized customer experiences. But data’s growth has also led to increased regulatory oversight around the world. For example, in the U.S. both state and federal laws govern data privacy, while both the European Union and United Kingdom each have their own GDPR frameworks.
additionalFields.headline: The best offense is a great defense

additionalFields.subHeadline: How United Airlines is transforming data into insights to stay ahead in a competitive space.
additionalFields.description: HOW OUR SOCIETY approaches air travel has undeniably changed over the last three volatile years. Beyond simply getting from point A to B safely and on time, passengers are now increasingly seeking a frictionless flying experience—one that can be provided best by airlines that have adopted cloud-based technologies and modernized their data strategies to personalize sales and redefine customer service. In this sense, United Airlines is setting a new bar. This isn’t surprising, as United has frequently pushed the competitive edge in a competitive industry: A champion of sustainable aviation fuel, the airline has a goal to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 100% by 2050. And while 50 percent of the company’s digital leadership roles are already occupied by women, the airline’s flight training academy plans to train 5,000 new pilots by 2030 and has set a goal that half of its pilot training program will consist of women and people of color.
additionalFields.headline: How United Airlines is transforming data into insights to stay ahead in a famously competitive space

additionalFields.subHeadline: Like most NFL teams, the Seattle Seahawks know the difference between wins and losses can be razor thin. The Seahawks leading the charge in applying data-driven insights to every corner of the franchise using AWS.
additionalFields.description: Not all factors impacting a game are controllable. But coaches and team management know that to stay competitive, they must leverage every tool at their disposal to get the most out of their players on game day. That’s why, when the Seahawks noticed a newly acquired asset in the backfield wasn’t reaching his impressive potential, they turned to the numbers. In a league where every advantage counts, the Seahawks are now leading the charge in applying data-driven insights to every corner of the franchise—using advanced Amazon Web Services (AWS) technologies to empower players to make critical split-second decisions, enable talent evaluators to balance their own instincts with quantifiable data, and much more.
additionalFields.headline: Safety in Numbers

additionalFields.subHeadline: In today's complicated landscape, startups need to understand what part of their data model is meaningful and empower teams with the right data tools. Learn how startups can extract more value from their data to create new products and speed innovation.
additionalFields.description: Cloud security company Wiz, a unicorn with a valuation of $6 billion, recently announced that it had reached annual recurring revenue of $100 million—only 18 months after launching its first product. Wiz achieved this growth by providing easy-to-use tools that help organizations quickly identify prioritize, remediate, and stave off potential cyberattacks.
additionalFields.headline: How Wiz, a $6 Billion Unicorn, Uses Specialized Data Tools to Fuel Innovation and Growth

additionalFields.subHeadline: How can a company move the needle on building a responsible AI program? For many companies, a key piece of the puzzle is education. The more you know, the better you can build.
additionalFields.description: The implementation of fair, responsible, and accurate AI is a top management priority for most companies, a recent report by BCG and MIT’s Sloan School has found. But only 52% of companies report having a responsible AI program in place. And of those, 79% say it’s not the kind of fully-implemented program they want. How can a company move the needle on building a responsible AI program? For many companies, a key piece of the puzzle is education. The more you know, the better you can build.
additionalFields.headline: Building more responsible AI

additionalFields.subHeadline: In today’s digital environment, brands must create highly personalized content experiences for every customer, across every interaction, every time. The key lies in modern data targeting.
additionalFields.description: IN TODAY’S DIGITAL environment, most consumers are waking up to inboxes that are filled to the brim—a direct result of the non-stop competition of marketers for our attention. Some of that content is valuable and well-targeted; much of it is not. As a result, brands must create highly personalized content experiences for every customer, across every interaction, every time. The key for how brands can do that successfully lies in the what and how of modern data targeting: what data is being used, and how a brand is using it. Traditionally, many companies have relied on a collection of quick fixes—cookies, third-party data, incomplete or siloed first-party data, and the like—to try and personalize individual consumer messaging. But such an approach can’t consistently fuel the kind of advanced content targeting consumers now demand.
additionalFields.headline: The Next Generation of Customer Experiences -How Salesforce built a tool to help brands personalize every interaction

additionalFields.subHeadline: Discover how three software startups are leveraging artificial intelligence and machine learning to create new opportunities for growth.
additionalFields.description: Most startups arrive on the business playing field like minor league baseball teams coming to play the Yankees: they have fewer resources, fewer people on the bench, and little room for error. Hiring talent, developing a product, finding paying customers, and raising money is a lot to accomplish. And as any startup CEO can attest, doing more with less is the name of the game. In years like this one when VC funding is down, efficiencies become even more critical for companies getting off the ground.
additionalFields.headline: Building faster, bigger, smarter

additionalFields.subHeadline: The NFL has partnered with AWS to implement a cloud-based data strategy that uses analytics, machine learning, and artificial intelligence to gain a deeper understanding of every aspect of the game and build a better football experience for fans, players, and teams.
additionalFields.description: From pre-season to post-season, the National Football League (NFL) delivers fans a thrilling, action-packed three hours with each game. Behind the nation’s most popular league is a philosophy of continuous improvement best expressed by legendary Miami Dolphins quarterback Dan Marino, who said, “You can do more, you can always do more.” One way the NFL does more is by pursuing innovative, data-driven programs to improve player safety, help players achieve their full potential, and make the game more exciting for fans. Since 2019, the League has partnered with Amazon Web Services (AWS) to implement a cloud-based data strategy that uses analytics, machine learning (ML), and artificial intelligence (AI) to gain a deeper understanding of every aspect of the game and build a better football experience for fans, players, and teams
additionalFields.headline: Fueling the future of sports: How the NFL is using the cloud to change the game–on the field, in the stands, and in your home

additionalFields.subHeadline: Using predictive modeling, organizations are forecasting the future to help governments, businesses, and communities find opportunities to prevent environmental damage as well as economic and human loss.
additionalFields.description: A United Nations report, released in September 2022, revealed that greenhouse gas concentrations are rising to record highs, and climate change-related disasters, like hurricanes and floods, have increased five times over the last 50 years, killing an average of 115 people per day. The UN report also emphasized the importance of providing “early warnings [to] save lives and livelihoods from climate threats.” AWS customers around the world are working to do just that. Using predictive modeling, organizations are forecasting the future to help governments, businesses, and communities find opportunities to prevent environmental damage as well as economic and human loss.
additionalFields.headline: The power of prediction: How modeling the future can help increase sustainability

additionalFields.subHeadline: Innovation as the driving force for sustainability
additionalFields.description:
Sustainability is a societal initiative that aims for humans to co-exist on the planet over the long term. It touches everyone today: Earth’s billions of people, local and world governments, regulatory bodies, and notably, companies and their customers, employees, and investors, where the challenges of doing business as usual loom larger than ever.

Read More
additionalFields.headline: Empowering customers to drive sustainable solutions for a better future

additionalFields.headline: 6 Security Predictions CISOs Need to Know

additionalFields.subHeadline: In today's global economy, fortune favors businesses that can bring services and experiences to their customers quickly, while focusing on flexibility and agility to continuously improve.
additionalFields.description: For companies large and small, operating in the cloud is nothing new. But today’s most successful companies are taking their operations further by bringing the cloud closer to both themselves and their customers with hybrid cloud and edge computing. This new mindset cuts latency to the quick, creates lightning-fast information processing, and offers unprecedented flexibility, both for companies and their customers. The results involve everything from autonomous vehicles, to smart factories, to an edge that extends all the way to low-earth orbit.
additionalFields.headline: Innovation at the Edge

additionalFields.subHeadline: The cloud helps businesses of all sizes and across industries lower costs, increase productivity and accelerate innovation. But some applications need to stay on premises or at the edge to meet regulatory, speed and other requirements.
additionalFields.description: The cloud helps businesses of all sizes and across industries lower costs, increase productivity and accelerate innovation. But some applications need to stay on premises or at the edge to meet regulatory, speed and other requirements. As a result, many organizations rely on a hybrid of cloud, on-premises and edge solutions which can create a complex IT environment that requires developers to learn different APIs, tools, code and processes.
additionalFields.headline: Hybrid cloud and edge computing - productivity drivers

additionalFields.subHeadline: Businesses today are innovating at a scale never before seen, thanks in part to the explosion of data and advances in technology. From banking and gaming to healthcare and manufacturing, companies are in a bid to stay competitive, boost productivity and create fast, immersive experiences for customers.
additionalFields.description: Businesses today are innovating at a scale never before seen, thanks in part to the explosion of data and advances in technology. From banking and gaming to healthcare and manufacturing, companies are in a bid to stay competitive, boost productivity and create fast, immersive experiences for customers. To meet these demands, the search to bring cloud infrastructure and services as close to the data or end user is a top priority – making hybrid cloud and edge technology of particular interest. Amazon Web Services (AWS) brings years of cloud experience to help companies address the challenges no matter where the data or users are located – whether that is in a smart factory, as a part of a medical device, or anywhere at the edge.
additionalFields.headline: Innovation at the edge

additionalFields.subHeadline: Businesses across an increasing number of industries require a "cloud wherever it's needed" model to gain greater flexibility, accelerate digital transformation and innovate to increase efficiency and create differentiated products, services and end-user experiences.
additionalFields.description: Businesses across an increasing number of industries require a "cloud wherever it's needed" model to gain greater flexibility, accelerate digital transformation and innovate to increase efficiency and create differentiated products, services and end-user experiences. With AWS, businesses can bring the cloud closer to wherever data is generated or consumed to create a consistent and secure experience across all environments, enabling low latency and local data processing as well as compliance with data residency requirements.
additionalFields.headline: Hybrid cloud and edge computing - flexibility at the edge

additionalFields.subHeadline: To compete in today’s competitive market, businesses want to bring the cloud wherever it’s most needed – whether that is in the cloud, on premises or at the edge
additionalFields.description: Business today takes place anywhere and everywhere — from desktop to hand-held devices, from major cities to the ocean floor. Staying connected requires a more flexible cloud model so that companies can run technology closer to their customers and where their data are consumed. Often, this requires a cloud anywhere approach that can meet the response times needed, process data locally to help with cost, size, bandwidth and time constraints and store customer data in a specific location for regulatory reasons.
additionalFields.headline: Taking advantage of the cloud, wherever a business needs it

additionalFields.subHeadline: Conversation with CJ Moses, Chief Information Security Officer at AWS, and Clarke Rodgers, director of AWS Enterprise Strategy
additionalFields.description:
Discover what it takes to build a security organization from the ground up and design a security culture supported by innovative hiring practices. You'll hear all this and more in this discussion between CJ Moses, Chief Information Security Officer at AWS, and Clarke Rodgers, director of AWS Enterprise Strategy.

Listen Podcast
additionalFields.headline: 122: AWS Cloud Security — How it Started, Where It’s Headed

additionalFields.subHeadline: Today’s businesses need hybrid cloud and edge computing to keep up with the technological shift that is transforming how global operations are run and how information is shared
additionalFields.description: Businesses across the globe need the agility to bring services and experiences to their customers quickly while being flexible enough to continuously iterate and improve on their products and services. To produce this digital transformation, organizations need to bring the cloud closer to their data or their end users. Hybrid cloud and edge technologies seamlessly extend the cloud to where companies need it, regardless of where the data resides. Amazon Web Services (AWS) brings years of cloud experience for seamless and secure hybrid and edge experiences — whether that’s in the cloud, at a data center, a large metropolitan area, at a 5G network, a smart factory or building, or beyond
additionalFields.headline: Digital transformation at the edge

additionalFields.subHeadline: Researchers at the University of Sydney are building a digitized genomic library to meet Australia’s conservation goals.
additionalFields.description: At the University of Sydney’s Australasian Wildlife Genomics Group, Senior Research Manager Dr. Carolyn Hogg is creating a genomic legacy database and an online tool to assist with conservation efforts and breeding programs for Australia’s threatened species. The technology is accessible to conservation managers and researchers around the world and allows Dr. Hogg’s team to manage a massive amount of data on a small research budget, focus its energy on analytics (not IT), and move with the urgency that climate change demands.
additionalFields.headline: Cloud Technology Helps Scientists Move Faster to Save Endangered Species (RONIN)

additionalFields.subHeadline: Industry leaders do more than iterate, they reinvent.
additionalFields.description: Industry leaders do more than iterate, they reinvent. Learn why large global enterprises, government organizations, and startups all trust AWS to run their most important applications in the pursuit of ambitious goals.
additionalFields.headline: The Infrastructure Imperative: How Technology Innovation Improves the Human Experience

additionalFields.subHeadline: Digitalization has dramatically altered how businesses and consumers interact, increasing consumer expectations and improving companies’ abilities to meet them.
additionalFields.description: As business and IT leaders make decisions about how they develop and deliver digitally enabled experiences to meet consumer expectations, they must also consider the future trajectory of economic, regulatory and environmental forces that can impact their ability to meet consumer demands and their business implications. This article identifies three trends that have altered the course of CX digitalization and provides an outlook of how external forces will continue to impact business and tech strategies in the future.
additionalFields.headline: Balancing act: Delivering cutting-edge customer experiences amid changing demands and external disruptions

additionalFields.subHeadline: Learn how AI and decision intelligence are helping manage the food supply chain and feed millions of vulnerable people.
additionalFields.description: FareShare Greater Manchester (GM) has forged a partnership with a technology company called Peak. Also based in Manchester, Peak specializes in Decision Intelligence, which means the company uses its cloud-based platform built on Amazon Web Services (AWS) with Intel technology to help customers apply artificial intelligence (AI) to their decision-making processes. FareShare is working with Peak to use this intelligence to match supply and demand and increase the efficiency of food redistribution.
additionalFields.headline: Using AI to Fight Hunger in the U.K.

additionalFields.subHeadline: How AI assists in the reduction of hunger.
additionalFields.description: See how Peak, an AI company, is helping FareShare, a food redistribution charity, provide millions of meals to vulnerable people by managing the food supply chain and more effectively predicting donations. Powered by the AWS cloud with Intel technologies.
additionalFields.headline: How AI and the Cloud Help Reduce Hunger and Food Waste

additionalFields.subHeadline: Taking Hollywood blockbusters and award-winning web series postproduction to the cloud, Company 3 found new ways to collaborate globally, increase workflow efficiency, and expand its roster of diverse movie-making talent.
additionalFields.description: In its early days, the pandemic hit the $99 billion entertainment industry particularly hard. People staying home from movie theaters led to a precipitous drop in theatrical revenue, while demand for streaming content grew almost immediately. Subscriptions to streaming services in the U.S. jumped 14% in 2021 alone, and the digital movie market accounted for 72% of the global theatrical and home/mobile entertainment market in 2021, up from just 48% in 2019, according to the Motion Picture Association.But filling the entertainment pipeline to meet demand suddenly proved to be a major challenge.
additionalFields.headline: Changing the Face of Moviemaking

additionalFields.subHeadline: Content by AWS and Intel.
additionalFields.description: Explore how customers are using the AWS cloud with Intel technologies to power a broad range of applications to help optimize food supply chains, transform capital markets, discover soccer talent around the world, change the face of moviemaking, and save endangered species.
additionalFields.headline: Cloud Innovation for Virtually Every Application

additionalFields.subHeadline: How AI and ML assist amateur footballers.
additionalFields.description: AiSCOUT is a UK-based technology company creating equal opportunity for talented amateur soccer players with its platform that runs from any smartphone and uses AI, machine learning, motion tracking, and data analytics powered by the AWS cloud and Intel technology.
additionalFields.headline: Discovering Diverse Talent with AiSCOUT

additionalFields.subHeadline: How AWS improved hybrid cloud and edge cloud computing.
additionalFields.description: AWS hybrid cloud solutions allow customers to bring cloud infrastructure and services where needed, enabling them to quickly start using the cloud.
additionalFields.headline: Designing a Hybrid Cloud Solution

additionalFields.subHeadline: Improved reliability and latency enable AWS Nitro SSD customers to more efficiently use their resources, using less energy to perform the same storage tasks.
additionalFields.description: Search engines may make people’s lives easier, but they can present challenges for service providers. Not only do customers expect instant results, but they also want the search engine to finish their thought, predicting what words may come next. These large search queries are complex, requiring extra computing power to tackle a demanding and wide-ranging number of queries—which in turn requires a heavy amount of input and output (I/O) operations to perform quickly.
additionalFields.headline: Rethinking Storage Unlocks Cloud Performance

additionalFields.subHeadline: Learn how AWS created purpose-built machine learning chips, Inferentia and Trainium, for powerful and cost-effective ML.
additionalFields.description: Machine Learning (ML) is powering breakthroughs that impact every aspect of our lives: cars that drive themselves, voice assistants that hold conversations, and even software that writes messages and creates photorealistic images with only a text prompt. From legacy enterprises to startups in every industry, companies are using this fast-evolving technology to solve problems in new ways.
additionalFields.headline: Unleashing Machine Learning for all

additionalFields.subHeadline: Built-in features that provide better protection and privacy
additionalFields.description: Security threats are constantly evolving. AWS will continue to develop new ways of helping customers protect their sensitive data.
additionalFields.headline: Three Ways Confidential Compute Offers a More Secure Cloud

additionalFields.subHeadline: Once in a blue moon, true organizational transformation can take less than 24 hours.
additionalFields.description: AWS stays one step ahead of the market by innovating on behalf of our customers. So when Apple developers started calling for a service that would let them build and run macOS workloads in the cloud, we knew it was time yet again to do something that has never been done before.
additionalFields.headline: Bye, Bye Bender

additionalFields.subHeadline: Go inside worlds powered by AWS Outposts, a family of on-premises solutions that bring industries like food-service, manufacturing, and healthcare a consistent AWS experience for smaller-capacity needs.
additionalFields.description: Alexis Gay welcomes special guest Tatiana Cooke, Principal Product Manager for AWS Outposts. Go inside worlds powered by AWS Outposts, a family of on-premises solutions that bring industries like food-service, manufacturing, and healthcare a consistent AWS experience for smaller-capacity needs.
additionalFields.headline: Discover What’s New With the AWS Outposts Family

additionalFields.subHeadline: The very first conversation inside the AWS Cloud Cafe, where reinventing hybrid cloud is always on the menu.
additionalFields.description: Series host Alexis Gay welcomes George Elissaios for the very first conversation inside the AWS Cloud Cafe, where reinventing hybrid cloud is always on the menu. George, General Manager for Hybrid and Edge Computing at AWS, shares innovations that allow AWS to deliver on the promise of bringing the cloud to wherever customers need it.
additionalFields.headline: Step Inside the AWS Cloud Cafe

additionalFields.subHeadline: Learn about encryption built on the cloud
additionalFields.description: As more and more companies are forced to grapple with sensitive consumer data, developers have become increasingly burdened with complex security processes that stretch beyond their skillset. Evervault, a leader in encryption infrastructure for developers is here to change that in collaboration with AWS.
additionalFields.headline: Encryption Made Easy

additionalFields.subHeadline: Learn how AWS reinvents cloud infrastructure to increase performance, reduce cost, enhance security, and accelerate innovation in the cloud, on premises, and at the edge.
additionalFields.description: Organizations across all industry are migrating to the cloud to eliminate expensive data centers, increase efficiency and reduce costs. All clouds, however, are not created equal.
additionalFields.headline: Making the Impossible Possible

additionalFields.subHeadline: AWS Cloud Cafe series host Alexis Gay brings two new special guests to the table to talk about how AWS Outposts, AWS Local Zones, and AWS Wavelength are rooted in the AWS culture of listening to customers and responding with innovations that bring the cloud closer to where they are.
additionalFields.description: AWS Cloud Cafe series host Alexis Gay brings two new special guests to the table to talk about how AWS Outposts, Local Zones and Wavelength are rooted in the AWS culture of listening to customers and responding with innovations that bring the cloud closer to where they are. Jennifer Lin, Product Manager for AWS Outposts; and Rob Czarnecki, Senior Manager, Product Management, for AWS Outposts, visit the cafe to talk about the ways AWS is reinventing hybrid and edge so that customers can accelerate digital transformation, improve IT and developer productivity and efficiency and deliver differentiated services and end-user experiences.
additionalFields.headline: Reinventing Hybrid and Edge Through a Customer Lens

additionalFields.subHeadline: AWS and Verizon have teamed with AWS to create a cloud-based 5G solution for distributing content that will revolutionize the way you consume media.
additionalFields.description: Media and entertainment companies are producing increasingly immersive content across multiple formats, from scripted programs to newscasts. Consumers love the expanded choices—and they want their media wherever and whenever, without delay or interruption, on any device. That’s especially true at Bloomberg Media, where every day, 2,700 journalists produce over 5,000 stories that can move financial markets. If Bloomberg viewers and users can receive breaking headlines and critical financial market data earlier than elsewhere, then investors are able to quickly trade ahead of the competition. In a global financial system where every millisecond counts, the faster delivery of Bloomberg news and data can result in increased investment and business success.
additionalFields.headline: Welcome to the New World of Media and Entertainment

additionalFields.subHeadline: Learn more about AWS and business resilience at the Financial Tmes
additionalFields.description: Economic, social and cultural shocks create challenges for every business. But a new global survey from AWS reveals that when the going gets tough, the most resilient businesses use data to find answers from within.
additionalFields.headline: The answers within - Engaging employees through data, tools, training, and empowerment

additionalFields.subHeadline: Technology innovation is helping some of the largest producers of greenhouse gases to drastically cut emissions. Learn how they’re doing it.
additionalFields.description: Reducing carbon emissions usually comes down to achieving greater efficiency in the use of energy and materials. Improving efficiency requires detailed mapping and monitoring of very complex systems such as factories, electrical grids, HVAC systems and logistics routings. Increasingly, these environments are outfitted with sensors, and artificial intelligence excels at finding patterns in the huge amounts of data that these sensors collect, says Bratin Saha, vice president of machine learning services at Amazon.
additionalFields.headline: How five key industries use AI, machine learning and the cloud to meet their sustainability goals

additionalFields.subHeadline: Uncovering opportunities to improve efficiency and serve customers better
additionalFields.description: For companies in every industry, success often depends upon the ability to shift quickly to meet changing business conditions and customer expectations. Increasingly, organizations are using the cloud to transform their operations to achieve greater quality, efficiency, and speed.
additionalFields.headline: Videos: Transforming the Future, featuring Miriam McLemore and Richard Halkett

additionalFields.subHeadline: Learn now restaurants are using AWS to make fast food service more efficient and, yes, faster
additionalFields.description: AWS Outposts helps restaurant kitchens be more efficient with advanced technologies to turn each step of the burger-making process into data points that can be monitored, analyzed and managed in real time. AWS Outposts servers, a fully managed solution, provide infrastructure, services, APIs, and tools deployed on-premises at locations that are space- and capacity-constrained, like a fast-food restaurant, allowing decisions like order-processing and operations to be made locally and quickly.
additionalFields.headline: Hamburgers and the High-Tech Future of Restaurants

additionalFields.description: Learn how today’s leaders are innovating to fuel their cloud journey, turning ideas into action. Join this unique discussion with leaders from Johnson Controls Inc, Alliance Technology, Duke Energy, BMO Capital Markets, GeorgiaTech, and Warner Bros, Discovery to learn more.
additionalFields.headline: ExecLeaders Show Re:Invent Recap: Transforming Ideas Into Action

additionalFields.subHeadline: Learn more about AWS, the cloud, innovation, and more at Bloomberg.
additionalFields.description: As today's businesses discover that cloud solutions aren't one-size-fits-all, a reinvention of the hybrid cloud is underway Discover how your business can use the cloud to its advantage regardless of where your data or users are located.
additionalFields.headline: The AWS Cloud Cafe

additionalFields.subHeadline: Leanr more about how AWS uses data to understand their employees.
additionalFields.description: Workforce data can help companies understand their employees and create a culture of continuous learning, transforming talent to unlock value.
additionalFields.headline: Top Advice: How data can build a resilient and agile workforce

additionalFields.subHeadline: Richard Halkett, Worldwide Lead, Digital Innovation at AWS, discusses how the cloud has opened a new world for media audiences and media producers.
additionalFields.description: As consumers, our demands have changed. We want media experiences that are immediately available, interactive, varied, personalized and available across all devices. For an industry that relied less than a generation ago on DVDs and cable, this transformation has been profound. And it could not have happened in the same way, or as quickly, without the cloud.
additionalFields.headline: Moving Fast and Scaling Faster: How Media and Entertainment used the cloud to meet unprecedented demand

additionalFields.subHeadline: Miriam McLemore, AWS Enterprise Strategist, explains how to uncover opportunities for business growth, efficiency, and operational improvement across the consumer goods and manufacturing industries.
additionalFields.description: For manufacturers, the last few years have been tough. Even prior to 2020, issues such as sustainability, trade conflicts, cybersecurity, and an evolving workforce were driving change across the manufacturing sector. Since the well-known upheavals of the pandemic itself, new challenges have emerged. Labor constraints, logistics issues, component shortages, rising energy costs, and geopolitical volatility are now compounding an already complex environment.
additionalFields.headline: Cloud-Fueled Innovation For Today's Manufacturers

additionalFields.subHeadline: Cultivating a culture of continuous learning helps ensure every employee at your organization thrives. But what steps should employers take to build the optimum learning environment?
additionalFields.description: With cloud technology transforming every aspect of how organizations work, all employees should have a chance to learn how they can take advantage of the benefits. Moreover, improving cloud skills helps increase adoption of new systems and ensure people use them effectively. Financial services provider Absa created a Cloud Incubator initiative to support its digital transformation, and more than 4,500 employees have now received formal cloud skills training. “We did not just want to train the technical people,” says Daleen Pretorius, Head of Cloud Platforms, at Absa. “We wanted to train the tech and the non-tech people and the broader business as well.”
additionalFields.headline: How to create a culture of learning and build business resilience

additionalFields.subHeadline: How working backward from the customer led AWS to build its own computer chips.
additionalFields.description: Jeff Bezos, executive chairman of Amazon, once explained that sometimes to grow your business you need to “determine what your customers need and work backward, even if it requires learning new skills.” In other words, sticking to your core competency can sometimes limit your ability to serve customers. When you work backward, you start with the customer problem and use it to design a solution. With this approach, you’ll often find yourself in uncharted territory. It led us to create Amazon Web Services (AWS), Amazon Studios, Alexa, and more.
additionalFields.headline: When Should a Business Learn a New Competency?

additionalFields.subHeadline: The cloud helps create better experiences for everyone.
additionalFields.description: The number of people over 65 is expected to more than double over the next 30 years, and aging is one of the leading causes of hearing loss in adults. In fact, the WHO estimates by 2050, 10% of the world’s population will have disabling hearing loss. Digital solutions can play an important role in improving communications accessibility for people with hearing loss. For example, with an automatic speech recognition service, organizations can easily add speech-to-text capabilities to their applications, including the ability to attribute text to different speakers in a conversation. A leading AWS customer in the intelligence community has used speech recognition technology to add live captioning to its video teleconferencing solution.
additionalFields.headline: Innovate to Increase Accessibility and Inclusion

additionalFields.subHeadline: Overcome price increases and labor shortages with digital innovation.
additionalFields.description: “Industry 4.0” may sound like a buzz phrase, but the operations transformation taking place is real. As our manufacturing customers face rising materials and energy prices, labor shortages, and ambitious sustainability goals, I’m increasingly talking to them about using data with machine learning (ML) to completely reinvent production processes for greater efficiency and quality. Our manufacturing customers aren’t looking for incremental shifts; they want step-change improvements. And they want to transform their operations with cost-effective technologies that are easy to implement. With the cloud, they can do that.
additionalFields.headline: 3 Ways Computer Vision and IoT Can Transform Operations

additionalFields.subHeadline: How the cloud is fueling the most exciting innovations impacting our lives
additionalFields.description: Over the last year, CTO of Amazon Werner Vogels has seen some of the most technologically advanced organizations innovate using cloud solutions, such as artificial intelligence (AI), machine learning (ML), and computer vision (CV). Many of these innovations will drive meaningful improvements to the way we live in the coming years. Here are the five technology areas he's most interested in watching evolve in 2023
additionalFields.headline: 5 Technology Areas to Watch in 2023

additionalFields.subHeadline: Conversation with Miriam McLemore, AWS Enterprise Strategist
additionalFields.description:
In Part 2 of this re:Invent Las Vegas session, Enterprise Strategist Miriam McLemore highlights why transformation is different from any other project and challenges leaders to rethink their levers for change. Learn more about how finding the intersection between innovation and operational excellence can deliver value and results. 

Listen Podcast
additionalFields.headline: 121: Succeeding in Economies of Speed: Rethinking Your Levers, Part 2

additionalFields.subHeadline: How organizations keep ahead of growing resiliency demands with the cloud.
additionalFields.description: From social networks to e-commerce to healthcare systems to online education and even national security, IT infrastructure serves as the backbone of operations. And when it fails, the repercussions can be far-reaching. Designing, building, deploying, and procuring an infrastructure that can withstand disruptions of any type or scale is not resource efficient for even the largest organizations. It’s a huge investment of time and money, and requires experience and expertise that is not core to their business. That’s why more organizations are moving to the cloud.
additionalFields.headline: Reinventing Operational Resiliency

additionalFields.subHeadline: Conversations with Miriam McLemore, AWS Enterprise Strategist
additionalFields.description:
When leaders look to change their organization, they often begin with restructuring, defining new processes and guidelines, or granting exceptions to innovation units. However, transformation isn’t just about doing existing things better; it’s foremost about doing things differently. This session by Enterprise Strategist Miriam McLemore from AWS re:Invent in Las Vegas highlights why transformation is different from any other project and challenges leaders to rethink their levers for change. 

Listen Podcast
additionalFields.headline: 120: Succeeding in Economies of Speed: Rethinking Your Levers, Part 1

additionalFields.subHeadline: How Telefónica's Customer Obsession Delivers Results
additionalFields.description:
As Telefónica's Chief Digital Officer, Chema Alonso is responsible for the innovation of digital products, data, and platforms at one of the world’s largest telecommunications companies. Hear Alonso share how Telefónica's enterprise business enables innovation for their customers through new media, television and entertainment viewing experiences.

Watch the video
additionalFields.headline: From Iteration to Invention

additionalFields.subHeadline: Enterprise Strategists from Amazon Web Services provide insights into common business challenges
additionalFields.description: Organizations are producing more data than ever before – from industrial equipment, digital media, and social networks, to online transactions and more. Every business wants to unleash the value of this data, but most organizations struggle to move beyond simply producing, collecting, and storing massive amounts of information..
additionalFields.headline: How do I attract job candidates with a diverse set of backgrounds?

Join Clarke Rodgers, director of AWS enterprise strategy as he interviews amazon’s chief security officer, Steve Schmidt about what it takes to establish a security culture, scale securely, and continuously adapt to changing circumstances.

additionalFields.description:
In this episode of Conversations With Leaders, we’re talking about the human side of digital transformation in government. Join Sarah Ryle from the AWS Institute as she speaks with Mike Beaven, Senior Manager of Government Transformation at AWS, about the impact that government service modernization can have on the everyday lives of citizens.

additionalFields.description: Companies like yours are realising the limitations of traditional business models—and the need to reinvent themselves. We surveyed 10,000 senior decision-makers to see how they're transforming. Discover the six steps they're taking to adapt for the future of work - and how you can do the same.
additionalFields.headline: The six steps to reinvention

ExecLeaders is an invite-only, global community for business and technology leaders, featuring current affairs-style shows, discussion panels, events, and inspiring content from international leaders in business, academia and public service.

additionalFields.description: How do you drive the cultural change that's so necessary for digital transformation and what does that looks like in the world of finance, where traditional banks are competing with fintech start-ups that were born in the cloud? In this episode of AWS Conversations with Leaders, Mark Holt (CTO of 10x Banking) gives you all the answers.

additionalFields.description:
How do you drive organizational and even cultural change in boardrooms and entire businesses to make digital transformation a success? What does that look like in the fast-moving world of banking, where huge highly-regulated incumbents are battling nimble fintech start-ups who were born in the cloud? In this episode of AWS Conversations with Leaders, Mark Holt, CTO of 10x Banking shares his insight about how to make a success of transformation, and the big shifts in mindset needed to get there.

additionalFields.subHeadline: And put them at the heart of your business
additionalFields.description: Business leaders are placing an increased emphasis on their environmental, social and governance (ESG) goals. Find out how cloud-based tools can provide real-time ESG insights, turning corporate commitments into measurable results.
additionalFields.headline: How to Monitor ESG Goals

additionalFields.subHeadline: A conversation with Jake Burns, Enterprise Strategist, AWS and Gregor Hohpe, Enterprise Strategist, AWS
additionalFields.description:
Does your leadership team suffer from the "fear of missing out" on the next technological advancement, leading to impulsive decisions or strategy shifts? How can you evaluate an innovative new offering to determine if it will create actual value for your organization? In this episode, AWS leaders tackle long and short-term planning, talent development, digital transformation, and more tools to help Executives avoid "FOMO".

additionalFields.subHeadline: Our Climate Connections eBook shows how AWS is helping organizations tackle climate change at scale
additionalFields.description:
Climate change is a primary driver of numerous calamities including floods, fires, diseases, droughts, and even ecosystem collapse. These disasters pose significant risks to human health and wellbeing, especially for our most vulnerable communities. Indeed, Adam Selipsky, CEO of AWS has called climate change the issue of our generation. Yet individuals and organizations are rising to the challenge and working to monitor and forecast climate change, mitigate its impact, and find solutions. To build these solutions, people need access to the best available data, science, and technology.

Read more
additionalFields.headline: Fighting Climate Change with the Cloud

additionalFields.subHeadline: Minimizing Environmental Impact with a Culture of Innovation
additionalFields.description:
About 85% of the world’s population is already being affected by human-driven climate change, a Nature Climate Change study finds, and nearly 70% of all economic sectors worldwide are impacted, according to Deloitte research. The Climate Connections eBook provides a guide to help customers bring these resources together with the cloud and offers insights from AWS climate experts across both public and private sectors. C-suite and leaders can learn how AWS customers achieve their climate adaptation, resilience, and sustainability goals.

Read More
additionalFields.headline: Sustainability & ESG

additionalFields.subHeadline: By Dr. Werner Vogels, VP & CTO at Amazon.com
additionalFields.description:
Dr. Werner Vogels is Chief Technology Officer at Amazon.com where he is responsible for driving the company’s customer-centric technology vision. Read his top 5 tech predictions for 2023 and beyond.

Read More
additionalFields.headline: Werner Vogels' Tech Predictions for 2023 and Beyond

additionalFields.subHeadline: A conversation with Jake Burns, Enterprise Strategist, AWS and Gregor Hohpe, Enterprise Strategist, AWS
additionalFields.description:
Can enterprises ever truly "future-proof" their organization? Predictions have become less and less reliable, and five year plans less realistic. How can leaders keep their organizations nimble and responsive to whatever comes, while also being intentional about growth and resource allocation? Join two AWS leaders as they discuss how to think about "future-readiness" as an alternative framework.

Listen Podcast
additionalFields.headline: 114: Future-Proofing is a Flawed Concept

additionalFields.subHeadline: Don’t let outdated concerns hold back your business
additionalFields.description: A common misconception about the cloud is that once you migrate, you’re forever stuck with the same provider. Read this blog to find out why vendor lock-in is actually a myth, and see how the cloud offers more flexibility to "lift and shift" your data than you might think.
additionalFields.headline: Misunderstandings about vendor lock-in

additionalFields.subHeadline: Transform and adapt with lessons from cloud-built businesses.
additionalFields.description:
Digital transformation is essential to maintain business resilience, deliver for customers, and stay competitive in the market. But differences in architecture, workloads, and resources make the journey unique for every organization. In this report, we share advice and best practices from IT leaders who have led digital transformation initiatives across both traditional enterprises and born-in-the-cloud organizations.

additionalFields.description: Cloud computing, when first introduced, relied on off-the-shelf components: hardware and software designed to support on-premises data centers, not shared resources in the cloud. Today, however, customer needs have changed dramatically. Millions of organizations, such as SmugMug, Airbnb, and Capital One, are in the cloud, and the performance and bandwidth they require continues to increase as the amount of data they process grows. In addition, customers expect faster responses today than they did only 10 years ago. In short, the traditional architecture used to initially develop the cloud could not keep up with these growing demands
additionalFields.headline: Cloud Optimization from the Ground Up

additionalFields.subHeadline: The International Space Station (ISS) is mankind’s most rarefied laboratory, a place where experiments can be performed under extended periods of true microgravity. Learn how AWS Snow Family devices are helping the ISS store and process data in space.
additionalFields.description: The International Space Station (ISS) is mankind’s most rarefied laboratory, a place where experiments can be performed under extended periods of true microgravity. During its more than two decades in operation, the ISS has hosted more than 2,000 experiments by scientists from around the globe, on topics ranging from cancer research and biotech to explorations of chemistry and physics. However, scientists on orbit have had to work without a key tool used in most modern laboratories: a sophisticated data center for processing their results.
additionalFields.headline: Space: the cloud's final frontier

Doing so is like taking the skills you learned from riding a bike and applying them to Formula 1: it will not work. You need to apply new paradigms, take advantage of new capabilities, and shift your mindset to truly become more agile in your product-development process. For example, as part of its efforts to unlock different human genomes, AstraZeneca is working toward the analysis of up to 2 million individual genomes by 2026. additionalFields.headline: At AstraZeneca, data and AI are more than game changers – they are life changers

additionalFields.description: Edge computing is ushering in a new era of technology. Operating seamlessly with the cloud, the edge allows organizations to meet the challenge of this ever-more-connected world, where we are all reliant on applications that must function anywhere and everywhere. With the edge, the benefits of the cloud—lower costs, increased agility, ability to scale up and down as needed, faster innovation—can be extended from the cloud to the precise locations where they are needed most.

If passed with an effective date in December 2022, these new climate reporting requirements would be phased in from fiscal year 2023 to fiscal year 2027.

Graviton is designed to provide customers with compute instances with the best price performance in Amazon EC2, while also using less power to improve sustainability.

additionalFields.description: The ability to pivot quickly to address rapidly changing customer or market demands is driving the need for real-time data. But poor data quality, siloed data, entrenched processes, and cultural resistance often present roadblocks to using data to speed up decision making and innovation. We asked the CIO Experts Network, a community of IT professionals, industry analysts, and other influencers, why real-time data is so important for today’s business and how data helps organizations make better, faster decisions. Based on their responses, here are four recommendations for improving your ability to make data-driven decisions.

Ten years ago, Salas noted, if a company wanted to build software or AI and ML solutions, “typically you had to build it yourself.” But now, the “beauty of AWS” is that it offers companies like Camino Financial “access to infrastructure, such that you don’t have to build everything from scratch.”

additionalFields.description: With so much diverse data available, why do so many companies still struggle to embrace the real-time, data-driven decision-making they need to be more agile? One thing is clear: The challenge isn’t solved by technology alone. “You can’t buy transformation,” says Tom Godden, Principal Technical Evangelist with the Enterprise Strategy team at AWS. “Real change doesn’t come just from new technology—it comes from rethinking your processes, which are enabled by the technology.”

additionalFields.subHeadline: Ars Technica set out to discover whether no-code-required tools could outperform a code-based approach. In the finale of the experiment, find out how the no-code tools performed.
additionalFields.description: To see how much machine learning tools for the rest of us had advanced—and to redeem myself for the unwinnable task I had been assigned with machine learning last year—I took a well-worn heart attack data set from an archive at the University of California-Irvine and tried to outperform data science students' results using the "easy button" of Amazon Web Services' low-code and no-code tools.
additionalFields.headline: Machine learning, concluded: Did the “no-code” tools beat manual analysis?

additionalFields.description: This is the second episode in our exploration of "no-code" machine learning. In our first article, we laid out our problem set and discussed the data we would use to test whether a highly automated ML tool designed for business analysts could return cost-effective results near the quality of more code-intensive methods involving a bit more human-driven data science.
additionalFields.headline: Setting our heart-attack-predicting AI loose with “no-code” tools

additionalFields.description: Over the past year, machine learning and artificial intelligence technology have made significant strides. Specialized algorithms, including OpenAI's DALL-E, have demonstrated the ability to generate images based on text prompts with increasing canniness. Natural language processing (NLP) systems have grown closer to approximating human writing and text. And some people even think that an AI has attained sentience. (Spoiler alert: It has not.)
additionalFields.headline: No code, no problem—we try to beat an AI at its own game with new tools

Here are four key takeaways from their responses.
additionalFields.headline: 4 ways to create better customer experiences with data

additionalFields.description:
The recent market downturn has many of us feeling uncertain and finding ways to do more with less. Modern organizations are taking advantage of the cloud to keep customers happy and employees energized, all while efficiently using scarce resources. Nowhere is this truer today than in customer service organizations.

Read More
additionalFields.headline: 3 Ways Great Customer Service Can Help Grow Your Business

additionalFields.subHeadline: by Mark Schwartz, Enterprise Strategist, AWS
additionalFields.description:
We often recommend that enterprises have a clear idea of what they hope  to accomplish by moving to the cloud. They can then set up success  measures that will both guide them and allow them to measure their  progress. In this blog post, Nurani Parasuraman discusses how best to  track the effectiveness of cloud adoption. 

Read More
additionalFields.headline: Tracking the Effectiveness of Cloud Adoption

additionalFields.subHeadline: Learn how AWS customers have maximized the business value of their AI investments.
additionalFields.description: We routinely underestimate the effects that new technology has in the long run while also overestimating its impact in the short term. What has become known as Amara’s Law, in honor of the late researcher and scientist Roy Amara, is playing out now in many organizations that adopt artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML) technologies. AI/ML has capabilities that seemed science fiction not long ago, from autonomous driving to image recognition and advanced robotics, with surely many more on the way. At the same time, even advanced enterprises can struggle to achieve the anticipated return on their AI/ML investments. Although expectations might have been set high, following several guidelines has helped our customers maximize the business value delivered by their AI/ML initiatives. We’ll share them in this AI/ML blog post mini-series.
additionalFields.headline: How organizational learning can unlock more business value from machine learning

additionalFields.subHeadline: CIOs are often caught between the C-suite’s desire to be cutting edge without fully understanding the problem or complexity the technology is meant to solve. Here’s how to address the conflict.
additionalFields.description: I empathize with the frustrations many CIOs experience as the latest fad hits their desks. From nowhere a demand pops up that a particular technology is urgently needed to modernize their company. The problem to solve is fuzzy, and desired outcomes unclear. I recall a skit from a peer at a team event years ago. In it he emulated one of those executives we’ve all met who, after leaving a long flight, rushes into the office and declares that “technology X,” featured in an in-flight magazine, is exactly what our company needs. It was one reason a favorite retort of mine became, “Thank you for the solution, now what was the problem?” when confronted with this behavior. It’s the silver bullet syndrome at its finest: a desire to be cutting edge without fully understanding the underlying problem or complexity.
additionalFields.headline: Overcoming the silver bullet syndrome: How to turn data dreams into reality

additionalFields.subHeadline: Navina is using AI to make data work for physicians, not against them, leveraging the full AWS toolkit to improve the human-to-human interactions at the heart of healthcare.
additionalFields.description: Healthcare is deeply human, and each successful doctor-patient interaction is unique. Some patients feel the most reassured by a straight-forward physician in a white coat; others respond better to a warm and humorous bedside manner. But if there’s one thing nobody wants their doctor to be, it’s overwhelmed. In addition to the detrimental effects on the doctors themselves, rampant burnout among healthcare providers puts patients at risk.
additionalFields.headline: How one healthcare startup is making data work for doctors and patients

additionalFields.subHeadline: What makes a good CDO? Discover what roles they can play to make the most impact.
additionalFields.description: I have been privileged to meet executives from every sector, many with the newer title of “CDO.” The “D” usually stands for Digital or Data. Here’s my observation from seeing great CDOs in action: they actively work to put themselves out of a job or, rather, to make the job they have unnecessary. They need to be different, not one more creator of a new silo nor a burgeoning empire of new ideas. Neither are they there just to digitize what is already being done.
additionalFields.headline: The CDO: Chief Disappearing Officer

additionalFields.subHeadline: Learn about amplifying purpose through technology.
additionalFields.description: In an interview with Forbes, Sean Salas explains how artificial intelligence has helped Camino Financial support entrepreneurs in new ways.

additionalFields.subHeadline: Learn how startups are putting their data to work with AWS to innovate faster.
additionalFields.description: AWS is committed to making AI and ML more accessible for any organization—regardless of its size or industry. We’ve developed AI and ML services that don’t require writing code or hiring data scientists to use. As a result, AWS has seen a dramatic increase in the adoption of these services across the startup community. AWS supports many entrepreneurs who have a vision for solving problems with enormous human impact. They’re using the cloud to not only build thriving businesses but also transform lives, communities and the world at large.

additionalFields.description:
In my customer conversations, Supply Chain Management (SCM) has become almost as constant a theme as people and agility. The last two years of pandemic and other disruptive events, along with the necessity to achieve sustainability objectives, have shocked companies into realising that they don’t necessarily know as much about their supply chains as they thought they did. Two of my colleagues, Dimitrios Armenakis and Sebastian von Berg, share their observations of what the impetuses for change are and how you can start on your own journey to become both efficient and effective.

additionalFields.subHeadline: Learn how BMW, Nasdaq, and BP are implementing an end-to-end data strategy to drive business outcomes.
additionalFields.description: Across industries and enterprises, data continues to explode, increasing in volume, variety, and velocity. According to IDC estimates, 64.2 zettabytes of data was created or replicated in 2020, and the amount of digital data created from 2021-2025 will be more than twice the amount of data created since the advent of digital storage. Internet of things (IoT) data is the fastest growing segment, followed by social media and video. Given that one zettabyte is the equivalent of about 250 billion DVDs, it’s understandable that enterprises are struggling to keep up.
additionalFields.headline: 3 capabilities to get more value out of your data

additionalFields.subHeadline: Businesses are facing increasing pressure from regulators, shareholders, customers and employees to operate more sustainably, and are turning to technology and digital transformation to enable innovative ways of reducing their carbon footprint.
additionalFields.description: Moving corporate computing functions from on-premises servers to cloud-based AWS systems can lead to energy efficiency gains of up to five times, and a reduction in workload carbon footprint by nearly 80 percent and up to 96 percent once AWS is powered with 100 percent renewable energy—which it is on pace to meet by 2025. Those gains come in the form of greater capacity utilization, services that can be turned on and off as needed, and the fact that cloud providers like AWS typically use the most state-of-the-art, energy efficient systems and infrastructure. In a further nod to sustainability, an Amazon official said during a February call with analysts that AWS would reduce e-waste by extending the life of the servers powering its cloud systems from four years to five, and networking equipment from five years to six.
additionalFields.headline: Cloud, digital transformation hold key to sustainable business

additionalFields.subHeadline: How can we create a tool that lets engineers bake an encryption earlier in the development process and make it easy?
additionalFields.description: Data security is top priority when building a product in its early stages, but not all software developers have expertise in it. The team at Evervault sought a solution and used AWS' Nitro Enclaves to create it. The result of this collaboration is Evervault Encryption Engine - or E3 - which provides highly constrained compute environments where sensitive data can be securely decrypted and processed. Since AWS and Nitro Enclaves are globally available on demand, Evervault easily provides affordable and secure encryption tools to developers everywhere, allowing for all software developers to ensure data security.
additionalFields.headline: Encryption Built on the Cloud

additionalFields.subHeadline: Fortnite from Epic Games is a free to play, always evolving multiplayer game, where anyone can collaborate to create their own world or battle to be the last one standing. But how does Epic support millions of gamers when a user-generated world goes viral?
additionalFields.description: Online gamers have the potential to create entire worlds - but when a surge of players join, the processing power needed for the game to run increases dramatically. Amazon EC2 helps these world-building games, like Fortnite from Epic Games, scale seamlessly so players get an uninterrupted, immersive experience with cost efficiency, allowing anyone to be the creator of the next biggest game.
additionalFields.headline: How Epic Games and AWS Empower Users to Create the Next Great Gaming Experience

additionalFields.subHeadline: Nowadays, virtual assistance or chatbots play an increasingly important role in providing quality customer support. additionalFields.description: Chatboxes serve an important role in customer service, and some require knowledge of many languages to run globally, which can be costly and time-consuming. Autodesk uses AWS Inferentia to help its chatbox, AVA, route questions through multiple ML models at once and generate responses in milliseconds - serving 5x the amount of customers at half the cost.
additionalFields.headline: How AWS Inferentia Enables Autodesk to Expertly Answer Over 100,000 Questions Per Day

additionalFields.description: Today we don’t think twice about using the internet to book a yoga or spin class, schedule a massage, or set up a float-tank session. However, it wasn’t always this simple. There was a time when we had to call the spa to make the appointment, and jot it down in our FiloFaxes. From the business’s perspective, it meant owners and managers spent time and energy dealing with the logistics and infrastructure of their offerings rather than developing better services for customers. We now think of this era as pre-Mindbody.
additionalFields.headline: By adopting a flexible technology strategy, Mindbody has taken its business to the next level

Many enterprises have already become proficient with the cloud. They’ve migrated a substantial portion of their workloads, learned the necessary cloud skills, established an aggressive security posture, and developed at least an initial workable operating model. What’s next? Here are some suggestions of how you build on that foundation to maximize the value of the cloud.

additionalFields.subHeadline: By Mark Schwartz, AWS Enterprise Strategist
additionalFields.description:
Throughout the year, we write blog posts on whatever topics seem to be most important to the AWS customer executives we speak to. Each of us on the Enterprise Strategy team holds 100-200 customer meetings a year, generally at the most senior executive levels, to try to help with their challenges in digital transformation—cultural change, organizational structure, company politics, governance models, investment strategies, and so on. Those meetings give us a chance to hear what’s on their minds. The year-end quiet period gives us a chance to look back over the year to see what patterns have emerged. In our annual blog post roundup, we go back over the year and organize our blog posts by theme.

Read the blog

additionalFields.description:

Here are five tips a CISO (or other CxO responsible for cybersecurity) can use to maximize their limited time with the BoD.

additionalFields.subHeadline: By Mark Schwartz, AWS Enterprise Strategist, and Nurani Parasuraman, AWS Customer Solutions
additionalFields.description:
“Shadow IT” or “Rogue IT”—I’d venture to say that all IT organizations experience it. It’s tempting for different parts of the business—when they feel that IT isn’t meeting their needs as quickly as they’d like—to find other ways to get things done. The problem is that they might be bypassing important security or availability controls, or creating IT functions that are impossible to maintain. In fact, IT sometimes appears slow because it is adding those security controls. And yet … the presence of shadow IT is often an indicator that business needs aren’t being met. When I was CIO of US Citizenship and Immigration Services, our solution was similar to what Nurani describes below, along with dramatically speeding up IT delivery through DevOps and the cloud.

Read the blog

But that entertainment void never happened. Instead, networks, studios, local TV stations, and other production houses turned to the cloud and got creative.

From talk shows featuring video chats with guests to new movies and series produced remotely with cloud-based tools, great entertainment choices continued to emerge.

In addition to being the right thing to do, taking ambitious climate action can spur innovation that helps a business and its customers. So, what do you do if you want to do more? Here are 3 steps companies can take to be more ambitious on climate – and ensure we reach the net-zero future we need.

additionalFields.description:
Data is more than an operational asset like factories, machinery, IP, and capital. Utilized correctly, data is an invaluable source of potential growth. The key is recognizing its inherent value, leveraging it intelligently, and creating a culture that embraces the power of being data-driven.

additionalFields.description:
What is a data-driven organization? What lessons can leaders learn from other organizations that use data to make step changes in performance? In this article, we answer these questions by exploring how the Municipality of eThekwini in South Africa is using data to address water scarcity issues through a transformation of people, processes, and technology. Harnessing the data scattered throughout the municipality, AWS is helping eThekwini leaders solve a pressing problem, ensuring that all their residents have a reliable supply of water and helping them jumpstart a data-driven culture for further innovation. Through their story, we can see the benefits of being a data-driven organization and how to get there.

Read more »
additionalFields.headline: Becoming data-driven: Lessons from tackling Durban’s water crisis

additionalFields.description:
The cloud helps companies reimagine energy production and use.

additionalFields.subHeadline: by Luc Hennekens, Enterprise Strategist, AWS
additionalFields.description:
Truth be told, most large organizations don’t exactly resemble perfectly tuned machines. In stark contrast is the breathtaking teamwork, focus, and precise execution we witness during Formula One (F1) pit stops. An F1 fan myself, I will explore the world of F1 in this blog post about digital transformation. Why? Because behind each on-podium champagne shower stands an ultra-high-performing, innovative, agile, and data-led organisation, obsessed with continuous improvement.

As much as the pit stop draws the attention, it actually isn’t the best example of collaboration in F1. In a pit stop, each individual performs a specific task with little interaction and with hardly any need for communication or creativity. The only interdependence is between the finish of one task and the start of the next and at the completion signal that releases the car back into the pit street.

So, let’s look beyond the pit stop to what F1 teams can teach us about agility, innovation, and the right culture.

Read more »
additionalFields.headline: Taking Pole Position in Your Industry: Agility in Formula One

additionalFields.subHeadline: A conversation with Dr. Tarika Barrett, CEO, Girls Who Code

“By failing to address the growing gender gap in tech, we’re failing to prepare our girls for the jobs of the future.” Dr. Tarika Barrett, CEO of Girls Who Code, joins Enterprise Strategist Miriam McLemore to discuss closing the gender and equality gap in IT, including making technology clubs available to girls and rethinking the recruitment and hiring process.

Listen on Spotify and Apple Podcasts
additionalFields.headline: Closing the Gender Gap in Technology

additionalFields.subHeadline: by Gregor Hohpe, Enterprise Strategist, AWS
additionalFields.description:
We routinely underestimate the effects that new technology has in the long run while also overestimating its impact in the short term. What has become known as Amara’s Law, in honor of the late researcher and scientist Roy Amara, is playing out now in many organizations that adopt artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML) technologies. AI/ML has capabilities that seemed science fiction not long ago, from autonomous driving to image recognition and advanced robotics, with surely many more on the way. At the same time, even advanced enterprises can struggle to achieve the anticipated return on their AI/ML investments. Although expectations might have been set high, following several guidelines has helped our customers maximize the business value delivered by their AI/ML initiatives. We’ll share them in this AI/ML blog post mini-series.

Read more »
additionalFields.headline: Unlocking the Business Value of Machine Learning—With Organizational Learning

additionalFields.description:
5G is more than just mobile bandwidth for communication services providers (CSPs). By combining 5G with AWS edge cloud services, 5G improves application performance for end users in countless industries, offering up to 10 times the speed of 4G. 5G can power emerging use cases like live video event streaming, smart cars and cities, Internet of Things (IoT), and augmented reality. Learn from Srinivasa Kalpala, VP Technology Strategy, Verizon and Dave Brown, VP EC2 AWS, about how 5G cloud-native private networks are now even easier to deploy with AWS, enabling a complete Industrial 4.0 revolution.

Listen on Spotify and Apple Podcasts
additionalFields.headline: Connecting the World of Tomorrow, Today, with 5G Edge Cloud

additionalFields.description:
Leveraging cloud technology to create personalized interactions across the customer journey.
